elements.content: To explore the influencing effect of different transition metal ions on the coordination geometries and structural architectures of metal–organic complexes with the same ligand, 10 new coordination compounds of a monobranched tripodal ligand N-[N′-(carboxymethyl)benzimidazol-2-ylmethyl]-N,N-bis(benzimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine (HAcNTB), namely, [Co6(AcNTB)6]·6ClO4·36H2O (Co-ClO 4 ), [Co6(AcNTB)6]·6BF4·9H2O·3CHCl3 (Co-BF 4 ), [Zn6(AcNTB)6]·6ClO4·2CHCl3·15H2O (Zn-ClO 4 ), [Zn6(AcNTB)6]·6BF4·52H2O (Zn-BF 4 ), [Ni2(AcNTB)2(H2O)2]·2ClO4·2CH3OH·2H2O (Ni-ClO 4 ), [Ni2(AcNTB)2(H2O)2]·2BF4·4CH3OH (Ni-BF 4 ), {[Mn(AcNTB)(CH3OH)]·ClO4·H2O} n (Mn-ClO 4 ), {[Mn(AcNTB)(CH3OH)]·BF4·H2O} n (Mn-BF 4 ), {[Cd(AcNTB)(CH3OH)]·ClO4·H2O} n ] (Cd-ClO 4 ), {[Cd(AcNTB)(CH3OH)]·BF4·H2O} n (Cd-BF 4 ) have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffraction, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. In isomorphous complexes Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , and Zn-BF 4 , the metal centers (Zn2+ and Co2+) are five-coordinated in a trigonal bipyramid geometry, leading to formation of hexameric rings through linkage of six metals and six ligands without coordination of anion and solvent molecules. In isomorphous complexes Ni-ClO 4 and Ni-BF 4 , the metal centers (Ni2+) prefer a six-coordinated octahedral geometry, resulting in dinuclear rings through connection of two metals and two ligands with water molecule participating in coordination. While in the isomorphous complexes Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 , the metal centers are seven-coordinated to form one-dimensional (1D) chain, showing an irregularly distorted geometry with water or methanol solvents entering coordination sphere. The coordination geometric preference of different metal ions with respect to the metal ionic radii and coordination numbers play an important role in determining the assembly fashions. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations have been performed to track the stability effects obtained by the metal ions in different coordination environments.

elements.content: Self-assembly of a monobranched tripodal ligand with different metal ions leads to formation of hexanuclear ring, dinuclear ring, and one-dimensional chain structures, which are directed by coordination geometric preference and size of the metal ions.
elements.clean_text: Self-assembly of a monobranched tripodal ligand with different metal ions leads to formation of hexanuclear ring, dinuclear ring, and one-dimensional chain structures, which are directed by coordination geometric preference and size of the metal ions.

elements.content: Crystal engineering of metal–organic coordination assemblies represents an engrossing area of research for scientists and engineers because of their fantastic chemical and physical properties. Over the past few decades, one great effort is devoted to the design and synthesis of new organic ligands as well as their effects on the structures and properties of coordination assemblies. Another important endeavor is to understand the impact of different metal ions in coordination compounds. This implies the subtle balances existing between the organic ligand and the metal coordination “algorithm”, which is one of the strategies guiding the design of new ligands. The advanced X-ray crystallographic technique currently dramatically accelerates discovery of crystal structures of new coordination compounds, and more and more coordination compounds assembled by the same ligand with different metal ions have appeared in literature. Nevertheless, the comparative study on the assembly process of one ligand influenced by different metal ions, either similar metal series like lanthanide cations (Ln3+), spherical d 10 cations (Zn2+ and Cd2+), and alkaline earth metal cations, or metal cations of distinct ionic size and electronic configurations (e.g., Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+), has been seldom investigated in a systematic manner. Recently, the self-assembly of dinuclear double-stranded or pentanuclear circular helicates from a bitridentate ligand with two d 10 cations (Zn2+ and Cd2+) were reported by Rice’s group. The final structures of the assembled helicates were controlled by the size of the metal ions. Similar results were also reported by Hancock, et al. Other reports demonstrated the effects of “soft” or “hard” natures of the metal ions on the structural versatility of their coordination assemblies. A series of helical Ln3+ complexes of chiral macrocycles have also been thoroughly investigated by Muller’s and Lisowski’s groups, and they found that the preferred helicity of the thermodynamic products was different in between the early and late Ln3+ ions. Furthermore, the tendency of some metal cations in forming specific secondary building units (SBUs) or cluster groups was found to be able to enrich the various kinds of coordination conformations.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering of metal-organic coordination assemblies represents an engrossing area of research for scientists and engineers because of their fantastic chemical and physical properties. Over the past few decades, one great effort is devoted to the design and synthesis of new organic ligands as well as their effects on the structures and properties of coordination assemblies. Another important endeavor is to understand the impact of different metal ions in coordination compounds. This implies the subtle balances existing between the organic ligand and the metal coordination "algorithm", which is one of the strategies guiding the design of new ligands. The advanced X-ray crystallographic technique currently dramatically accelerates discovery of crystal structures of new coordination compounds, and more and more coordination compounds assembled by the same ligand with different metal ions have appeared in literature. Nevertheless, the comparative study on the assembly process of one ligand influenced by different metal ions, either similar metal series like lanthanide cations (Ln3+), spherical d 10 cations (Zn2+ and Cd2+), and alkaline earth metal cations, or metal cations of distinct ionic size and electronic configurations (e.g., Mn2+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+), has been seldom investigated in a systematic manner. Recently, the self-assembly of dinuclear double-stranded or pentanuclear circular helicates from a bitridentate ligand with two d 10 cations (Zn2+ and Cd2+) were reported by Rice's group. The final structures of the assembled helicates were controlled by the size of the metal ions. Similar results were also reported by Hancock, et al. Other reports demonstrated the effects of "soft" or "hard" natures of the metal ions on the structural versatility of their coordination assemblies. A series of helical Ln3+ complexes of chiral macrocycles have also been thoroughly investigated by Muller's and Lisowski's groups, and they found that the preferred helicity of the thermodynamic products was different in between the early and late Ln3+ ions. Furthermore, the tendency of some metal cations in forming specific secondary building units (SBUs) or cluster groups was found to be able to enrich the various kinds of coordination conformations.

elements.content: Our previous research on a monobranched tripodal ligand, HAcNTB, disclosed that when this ligand reacted with various Cu2+ salts, different anions and solvent systems could induce the formation of three different coordination architectures, namely, meso-hexameric metallamacrocycle, chiral trimeric metallamacrocycle, and 1D chiral chain. We also noticed that the use of the structurally resembling perchlorate (ClO4 –) and tetrafluoroborate (BF4 –) anions led to the same kind of coordination architectures, [Cu6(AcNTB)6]·6ClO4·26H2O (Cu-ClO 4 ) and [Cu6(AcNTB)6](BF4)6·30H2O (Cu-BF 4 ). To extend our study on coordination chemistry of this monobranched tripodal ligand and investigate the influence of different transition metal ions on the structure of its coordination compounds, we report and compare here a series of coordination compounds assembled by this ligand with different metal cations of varied metal sizes and electronic configurations, namely, Mn2+ (d 5, 0.80 Å), Co2+ (d 6, 0.72 Å), Ni2+ (d 8, 0.69 Å), Cu2+ (d 9, 0.72 Å), Zn2+ (d 10, 0.74 Å), and Cd2+ (d 10, 0.97 Å). The counteranions are either ClO4 – or BF4 –, and the complexes are synthesized in similar conditions. The single-crystal structural analyses revealed three series of isomorphous complexes: (1) Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , and Zn-BF 4 which are hexanuclear rings similar to Cu-ClO 4 and Cu-BF 4 complexes reported before, (2) Ni-ClO 4 and Ni-BF 4 which are dinuclear rings, and (3) Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 which show up as 1D chain structures (Scheme ). To explore the relationship between different metal cations and their coordination conformations from the same HAcNTB ligand, density functional theory (DFT) calculations on the energies of Zn2+, Ni2+ and Cd2+ complexes in three different conformations based on the crystal structures have been performed.

elements.content: All complexes were readily obtained by slow evaporation of the mixture containing the corresponding hydrated transition metal salts and HAcNTB ligands in similar solvent system. Due to the presence of large voids in the crystal lattice of all complexes, a great number of solvent molecules participate in crystallization. The sort and amount of the solvated molecules involved in crystallization seems randomly dependent on the solvent system, which makes the discrepancy of the molecular formula between the single crystal data and bulk sample elemental analysis results for some complexes. Nevertheless, the phase purity of most complexes has been satisfactorily confirmed by the comparison of the powder X-ray diffraction patterns with the simulated ones on the basis of the single crystal data ( of the ). IR spectra have also been obtained for all complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation and Characterization

All complexes were readily obtained by slow evaporation of the mixture containing the corresponding hydrated transition metal salts and HAcNTB ligands in similar solvent system. Due to the presence of large voids in the crystal lattice of all complexes, a great number of solvent molecules participate in crystallization. The sort and amount of the solvated molecules involved in crystallization seems randomly dependent on the solvent system, which makes the discrepancy of the molecular formula between the single crystal data and bulk sample elemental analysis results for some complexes. Nevertheless, the phase purity of most complexes has been satisfactorily confirmed by the comparison of the powder X-ray diffraction patterns with the simulated ones on the basis of the single crystal data ( of the ). IR spectra have also been obtained for all complexes.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that the structures of coordination frameworks in Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , and Zn-BF 4 are the same as those Cu complexes reported previously, with the exception of the metal cations, forming a series of isomorphous crystals which differ not only in metal ions or counteranions (isomorphous displacement) but also solvent molecules (isomorphous addition). As shown in Figure , the metal ion (Co2+ or Zn2+) is encapsulated by an AcNTB– ligand which displays a fan-like conformation. The coordination geometry of the metal ion can be best described as a distorted trigonal bipyramid in which three N atoms from three benzimidazole groups of one AcNTB– ligand take the basal plane positions, while the apical N atom of the ligand as well as one carboxylate O atom from another ligand take the two axial positions. Such coordination motifs, [MAcNTB]+ (M = Cu2+, Co2+, or Zn2+) can be regarded as building blocks that are linked through the acetate groups to give a hexameric metallamacrocycle ([M6AcNTB6]6+ appearing as a giant wheel). The intramolecular π–π interactions are formed between every two face-to-face arranged benzimidazole groups, which point inward toward the center of the wheel, leading to the formation of a hydrophobic cavity inside the giant wheel. In addition, each [M6AcNTB6]6+ ring forms twelve N–H···O hydrogen bonds with twelve adjacent [M6AcNTB6]6+ rings, in which six noncoordinating carboxylate oxygen atoms serve as hydrogen acceptors and six abducent NH groups serve as hydrogen donors (Figure c). Therefore, a porous three-dimensional (3D) cationic framework which possesses large voids is generated by the aid of hydrogen bonding. The twelve N–H···O hydrogen bonds are 3̅ symmetry-related and the bond lengths are 2.753, 2.766, 2.792, and 2.729 Å for complexes Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , and Zn-BF 4 , respectively. In the huge voids, NH groups from the outward pointed benzimidazole groups provide a hydrophilic environment to accommodate guest anions (perchlorate anions for Co-ClO 4 and Zn-ClO 4 ; tetrafluorobrorate anions for Co-BF 4 and Zn-BF 4 ) and water molecules. The total potential solvent accessible voids per unit cell, 40.3% for Co-ClO4, 40.1% for Co-BF4, 41.5% for Zn-ClO4, and 39.1% for Zn-BF4, were calculated by the PLATON program. Due to the open, huge voids in the cationic frameworks, the anion exchange and selective inclusion of different guests in the cavity should be possible.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that the structures of coordination frameworks in Co-ClO  4 , Co-BF  4 , Zn-ClO  4 , and Zn-BF  4  are the same as those Cu complexes reported previously, with the exception of the metal cations, forming a series of isomorphous crystals which differ not only in metal ions or counteranions (isomorphous displacement) but also solvent molecules (isomorphous addition). As shown in Figure , the metal ion (Co2+ or Zn2+) is encapsulated by an AcNTB- ligand which displays a fan-like conformation. The coordination geometry of the metal ion can be best described as a distorted trigonal bipyramid in which three N atoms from three benzimidazole groups of one AcNTB- ligand take the basal plane positions, while the apical N atom of the ligand as well as one carboxylate O atom from another ligand take the two axial positions. Such coordination motifs, [MAcNTB]+ (M = Cu2+, Co2+, or Zn2+) can be regarded as building blocks that are linked through the acetate groups to give a hexameric metallamacrocycle ([M6AcNTB6]6+ appearing as a giant wheel). The intramolecular π-π interactions are formed between every two face-to-face arranged benzimidazole groups, which point inward toward the center of the wheel, leading to the formation of a hydrophobic cavity inside the giant wheel. In addition, each [M6AcNTB6]6+ ring forms twelve N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds with twelve adjacent [M6AcNTB6]6+ rings, in which six noncoordinating carboxylate oxygen atoms serve as hydrogen acceptors and six abducent NH groups serve as hydrogen donors (Figure c). Therefore, a porous three-dimensional (3D) cationic framework which possesses large voids is generated by the aid of hydrogen bonding. The twelve N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds are 3̅ symmetry-related and the bond lengths are 2.753, 2.766, 2.792, and 2.729 Å for complexes Co-ClO  4 , Co-BF  4 , Zn-ClO  4 , and Zn-BF  4 , respectively. In the huge voids, NH groups from the outward pointed benzimidazole groups provide a hydrophilic environment to accommodate guest anions (perchlorate anions for Co-ClO  4  and Zn-ClO  4 ; tetrafluorobrorate anions for Co-BF  4  and Zn-BF  4 ) and water molecules. The total potential solvent accessible voids per unit cell, 40.3% for Co-ClO4, 40.1% for Co-BF4, 41.5% for Zn-ClO4, and 39.1% for Zn-BF4, were calculated by the PLATON program. Due to the open, huge voids in the cationic frameworks, the anion exchange and selective inclusion of different guests in the cavity should be possible.

elements.content: It is worth mentioning that the fan-like conformation of the AcNTB– ligand in the [MAcNTB]+ coordination unit makes three benzimidazole groups arrange in either a right-handed or left-handed propeller fashion, giving rise to a pair of enantiomers. The steric conformation of adjacent building blocks in the hexameric wheel is opposite, thus resulting in meso-structures in compounds Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , and Zn-BF 4 .

elements.content: Representative crystal structures of Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , and Zn-BF 4 : (a) coordination geometry of M2+ cation (M2+ = Co2+/Zn2+, teal; N, blue; C, gray; O, red (in one ligand) and purple (from another ligand) showing fan-like conformation of the AcNTB– ligand; (b) space-filling diagram of the 3D framework viewed along [100] showing huge hydrophilic voids; (c) hexameric ring [M6AcNTB6]6+ showing twelve N–H···O hydrogen bonds in red dash lines, intramolecular π–π interactions in blue dash lines, and central metal ions in polyhedra (three benzimidazole groups in each ligand shown in different color for clarity); (d) hexameric ring [M6AcNTB6]6+ showing the hydrophobic cavity inside the ring highlighted by yellow ball. All guest molecules are omitted for clarity.

All guest molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Different from the above Cu2+/Co2+/Zn2+ complexes, the isostructures of Ni2+ compounds (Ni-ClO 4 and Ni-BF 4 ) feature in a centrosymmetric dinuclear unit, [Ni2AcNTB2(H2O)2]2+. The Ni2+ ion displays a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by four N atoms from one AcNTB–, one acetate O atom from another ligand and one O atom from a coordinated water molecule. Three benzimidazole groups from AcNTB– ligand in Ni-ClO 4 or Ni-BF 4 adopt pincer-like conformation which is different from the fan-like conformation in other compounds. As shown in Figure , the acetate groups link two pincer-like units in a face-to-face way to generate a dinuclear metallocycle, in which two intramolecular O–H···O hydrogen bonds (O···O: 2.620 for Ni-ClO 4 and 2.628 Å for Ni-BF 4 ) are formed by two noncoordinating O atoms from acetate groups with the coordinated water molecules. The stability of the dinuclear unit is therefore reinforced. In the crystal lattice, such dinuclear rings stack with the methanol and water solvent molecules and anions (ClO4 – for Ni-ClO 4 and BF4 – for Ni-BF 4 ) with weak intermolecular interactions. The crystals are unstable owing to easy loss of solvated molecules, which makes it difficult to obtain a satisfactory XPRD pattern for compound Ni-ClO 4 .

Three benzimidazole groups from AcNTB- ligand in Ni-ClO  4  or Ni-BF  4  adopt pincer-like conformation which is different from the fan-like conformation in other compounds. As shown in Figure , the acetate groups link two pincer-like units in a face-to-face way to generate a dinuclear metallocycle, in which two intramolecular O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (O⋅⋅⋅O: 2.620 for Ni-ClO  4  and 2.628 Å for Ni-BF  4 ) are formed by two noncoordinating O atoms from acetate groups with the coordinated water molecules. elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that complexes Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 form the third series of isomorphous crystals which have very similar unit cells and crystallize in the same space group, P2(1)/c. The asymmetric units of Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 are the same except for the metal cations (Mn2+ in Mn-ClO 4 and Mn-BF4 versus Cd2+ in Cd-ClO 4 and Cd-BF 4 ) or the counteranions (ClO4 – in Mn-ClO4 and Cd-ClO4 versus BF4 – in Mn-BF 4 and Cd-BF 4 ), which consist of one AcNTB– ligand, one metal cation, one counteranion, one coordinated methanol molecule, and one solvated water molecule. In complex Mn-ClO 4 , which is shown as a representative in Figure , Mn2+ cation displays a distorted 7-coordinating geometry with four N atoms from one AcNTB– ligand, two O atoms from the acetate group of another ligand and one O atom from the coordinating methanol molecule, resulting in an [M(AcNTB)(MeOH)]+ coordination unit. In this unit, the three benzimidazole groups take the same propeller direction and therefore are chiral as in Co-ClO 4 . The acetate groups join the coordination units of the same chirality to form a 1D chiral chain. In the crystal lattice, pairs of such enantiomeric 1D chian cocrystallizes in the same crystal and lead to racemate Mn-ClO 4 . Three types of intermolecular π–π interactions are observed between the benzimidazole rings from one chain to another, one face-to-face contact and two face-to-edge interactions, which connect the 1D chains into a 3D cationic frameworks. One tiny channel can be viewed from the [001] direction, in which the perchlorate anions and water molecules are accommodated. In its isostructures Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 , similar 1D chiral chain, π–π interactions, and 3D frameworks are observed.

The asymmetric units of Mn-ClO  4 , Mn-BF  4 , Cd-ClO  4 , and Cd-BF  4  are the same except for the metal cations (Mn2+ in Mn-ClO  4  and Mn-BF4 versus Cd2+ in Cd-ClO  4  and Cd-BF  4 ) or the counteranions (ClO4 - in Mn-ClO4 and Cd-ClO4 versus BF4 - in Mn-BF  4  and Cd-BF  4 ), which consist of one AcNTB- ligand, one metal cation, one counteranion, one coordinated methanol molecule, and one solvated water molecule. In complex Mn-ClO  4 , which is shown as a representative in Figure , Mn2+ cation displays a distorted 7-coordinating geometry with four N atoms from one AcNTB- ligand, two O atoms from the acetate group of another ligand and one O atom from the coordinating methanol molecule, resulting in an [M(AcNTB)(MeOH)]+ coordination unit. In this unit, the three benzimidazole groups take the same propeller direction and therefore are chiral as in Co-ClO  4 . The acetate groups join the coordination units of the same chirality to form a 1D chiral chain. In the crystal lattice, pairs of such enantiomeric 1D chian cocrystallizes in the same crystal and lead to racemate Mn-ClO  4 . Three types of intermolecular π-π interactions are observed between the benzimidazole rings from one chain to another, one face-to-face contact and two face-to-edge interactions, which connect the 1D chains into a 3D cationic frameworks. One tiny channel can be viewed from the [001] direction, in which the perchlorate anions and water molecules are accommodated. In its isostructures Mn-BF  4 , Cd-ClO  4 , and Cd-BF  4 , similar 1D chiral chain, π-π interactions, and 3D frameworks are observed.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the bond distances between the apical N atom of AcNTB– ligand and the central metal cations in complexes Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 are 2.602, 2.590, 2.674, and 2.669 Å, respectively, which are apparently longer than those in Co, Zn, Cu, and Ni complexes. In addition, the acetate groups, although acting as the bridges to implement coordination assembly as in other complexes, are bidentate to chelate metal centers, quite different from the monodentate coordination behaviors in other complexes. Therefore, the coordination geometry of Mn and Cd complexes may be described as a 7-coordinating monocapped trigonal prism, distinct from 5-coordinating trigonal bipyramid in Co, Cu, and Zn complexes and 6-coordinating octahedron in Ni complexes.

elements.content: Representative crystal structures of Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 : (a) coordination geometry of M2+ cation (M2+ = Mn2+/Cd2+, teal; N, blue; C, gray; O, red (in one ligand) and purple (from another ligand) showing fan-like conformation of the AcNTB– ligand; (b) 1D chiral chain bridged through bidentate acetate groups; (c) intermolecular π–π interactions between 1D chains showing in purple dash lines for face-to-face π–π interactions and in green and teal dash lines for two kinds of face-to-edge π–π interactions; and (d) space-filling diagram showing anions (ClO4 – for Mn-ClO 4 and Cd-ClO 4 , BF4 – for Mn-BF 4 and Cd-BF 4 ) and guest water molecules in the channel viewed along [001].

elements.content: From the crystal structures of the ten complexes discussed above and Cu2+ complexes reported before, we can see that the choice of the metal ions will lead to dramatic structural diversity in their coordination assembly process. As summarized in Figure , three different kinds of coordination geometries resulted, depending on the different metal centers, namely 5-coordinating trigonal bipyramid in Co, Cu, and Zn complexes, 6-coordinating octahedron in Ni complexes and 7-coordinating monocapped trigonal prism in Mn and Cd complexes. As a consequence, three different types of coordination structures were assembled, namely hexameric ring in Co, Cu, and Zn isomorphous series (Pa-3 series, Cu-ClO 4 , Cu-BF 4 , Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , and Zn-BF 4 ), dimeric ring in Ni isomorphous series (P2(1)/n series, Ni-ClO 4 and Ni-BF 4 ), and 1D chain in Mn and Cd isomorphous series (P2(1)/c series, Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 ).
elements.clean_text:
Structure Comparison and Assembly Mechanism

From the crystal structures of the ten complexes discussed above and Cu2+ complexes reported before, we can see that the choice of the metal ions will lead to dramatic structural diversity in their coordination assembly process. As summarized in Figure , three different kinds of coordination geometries resulted, depending on the different metal centers, namely 5-coordinating trigonal bipyramid in Co, Cu, and Zn complexes, 6-coordinating octahedron in Ni complexes and 7-coordinating monocapped trigonal prism in Mn and Cd complexes. As a consequence, three different types of coordination structures were assembled, namely hexameric ring in Co, Cu, and Zn isomorphous series (Pa-3 series, Cu-ClO  4 , Cu-BF  4 , Co-ClO  4 , Co-BF  4 , Zn-ClO  4 , and Zn-BF  4 ), dimeric ring in Ni isomorphous series (P2(1)/n series, Ni-ClO  4  and Ni-BF  4 ), and 1D chain in Mn and Cd isomorphous series (P2(1)/c series, Mn-ClO  4 , Mn-BF  4 , Cd-ClO  4 , and Cd-BF  4 ).

elements.content: Representation of different coordination structures assembled from six different transition metal ions in the periodic table of elements. The numbers below the cation symbols represent the cations’ radii (Å).
elements.clean_text: 4  Representation of different coordination structures assembled from six different transition metal ions in the periodic table of elements. The numbers below the cation symbols represent the cations' radii (Å).

elements.content: Since all complexes were assembled with the same ligand, similar anions (ClO4 – and BF4 –, both are highly symmetric and weakly coordinative) under comparable solvent systems, the assembly process is undoubtedly directed by the metal effect which should include three aspects: (a) crystal ionic radii of metal, (b) coordination geometric preference of metal, and (c) ligand conformation confined by metal. The crystal ionic radii of the divalent metal are in the order 0.69, 0.72, 0.74, 0.74, 0.80, and 0.97 Å for Ni2+, Cu2+, Co2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, and Cd2+, respectively (Figure ). Except for the smallest Ni2+ ion, an expectable coordination tendency is observed in these complexes. That is, the smaller metal centers such as Cu2+, Co2+, and Zn2+ favor lower coordination number of five, while the larger metal centers such as Mn2+ and Cd2+ prefer a higher coordination number of seven. However, different metal ions usually have preferential coordination geometry depending on their electronic configurations (d 5 for Mn2+, d 7 for Co2+, d 8 for Ni2+, d 9 for Cu2+, d 10 for Zn2+, and d 10 for Cd2+). According to the ligand field theory, the half filled d 5 (high spin Mn2+) and fully filled d 10 (Cd2+) metal ions take little contribution from the ligand coordination, and therefore prefer a flexible coordination geometry to accommodate as many donor atoms as possible. This is consistent with the observation of the highly distorted 7-coordinating monocapped trigonal prism for Mn and Cd complexes. In contrast, the d 8 (Ni2+) metal ion displays a strong preference to adopt an octahedral geometry due to the gain of the maximum ligand field stabilization energy. This obviously accounts for why the smallest Ni2+ ion favors 6-coordinating geometry in comparison with the 5-coordinating Cu2+, Co2+, and Zn2+ ions of slightly larger ionic radii. The trigonal bipyramidal geometry in Cu2+, Co2+, and Zn2+ complexes may be due to a balance between the metal coordination geometric preference and ligand conformation. For the free AcNTB– ligand, a fan-like pseudo C 3-symmetric conformation is evidently preferable. Upon coordination with Cu2+ and Co2+ ions, the trigonal bipyramid geometry is the best choice to retain the ligand fan-like conformation, causing little energy loss to rearrange three benzimidazole groups of the ligand while gaining reasonable ligand field stabilization energy by d-orbital splitting (Cu2+and Co2+). The Zn2+ ion adopts the trigonal bipyramidal geometry because of its comparable metal size with Cu2+and Co2+ ions and freedom in demanding coordination geometry like Mn2+and Cd2+ ions. In comparison, a pincer-like conformation of the ligand is observed in the Ni2+ complex in which the ligand field stabilization energy is strong enough to compensate for ligand rearrangement.

elements.content: On the basis of the above discussion, the metal effect, deriving from the subtly balanced metal size, electronic configuration and ligand conformation, exerts influence over coordination assembly process by fine-tuning of the metal coordination geometry. Because the coordination geometry determines the spacial orientation of the ligands around the metal centers, the coordination building blocks thereof contain necessary “instruction” to direct the assembly process, resulting in the corresponding outcome: hexameric ring for Cu2+, Co2+ and Zn2+ ions, dimeric ring for Ni2+ ions, and 1D chain for Mn2+ and Cd2+ ions. In addition, various intra- and intermolecular interactions may facilitate coordination assembly by stabilizing the product. In Co, Cu, and Zn isomorphous series, intramolecular π–π interactions are formed between adjacent benzimidazole groups in the hexameric ring. In Mn and Cd isomorphous series, various intermolecular π–π interactions are formed to stabilize the 1D chain packing, while in Ni isomorphous series, plenty of intra- and intermolecular hydrogen bonds are formed to consolidate crystal packing.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the above discussion, the metal effect, deriving from the subtly balanced metal size, electronic configuration and ligand conformation, exerts influence over coordination assembly process by fine-tuning of the metal coordination geometry. Because the coordination geometry determines the spacial orientation of the ligands around the metal centers, the coordination building blocks thereof contain necessary "instruction" to direct the assembly process, resulting in the corresponding outcome: hexameric ring for Cu2+, Co2+ and Zn2+ ions, dimeric ring for Ni2+ ions, and 1D chain for Mn2+ and Cd2+ ions. In addition, various intra- and intermolecular interactions may facilitate coordination assembly by stabilizing the product. In Co, Cu, and Zn isomorphous series, intramolecular π-π interactions are formed between adjacent benzimidazole groups in the hexameric ring. In Mn and Cd isomorphous series, various intermolecular π-π interactions are formed to stabilize the 1D chain packing, while in Ni isomorphous series, plenty of intra- and intermolecular hydrogen bonds are formed to consolidate crystal packing.

elements.content: To obtain more evidence concerning the effects of metal ions on the coordination conformations, models created from fragments of the crystal structures were studied theoretically using DFT calculations. The geometries of Zn2+/Ni2+/Cd2+ metal centers in three different kinds of coordination units were optimized based on the fragments of crystal structures as shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

To obtain more evidence concerning the effects of metal ions on the coordination conformations, models created from fragments of the crystal structures were studied theoretically using DFT calculations. The geometries of Zn2+/Ni2+/Cd2+ metal centers in three different kinds of coordination units were optimized based on the fragments of crystal structures as shown in Figure .

elements.content: Theoretical view of the three different coordination models, (a) fragment in hexameric metallacycle (abbreviated as M-H); (b) fragment in dinuclear metallacycle (abbreviated as M-D); and (c) fragment in 1D chain (abbreviated as M–C). M = Zn, Ni, Cd.
elements.clean_text: 5  Theoretical view of the three different coordination models, (a) fragment in hexameric metallacycle (abbreviated as M-H); (b) fragment in dinuclear metallacycle (abbreviated as M-D); and (c) fragment in 1D chain (abbreviated as M-C). M = Zn, Ni, Cd.

elements.content: Table lists the crystal data and structure refinement summary for complexes. Table lists the energies of the Zn2+/Ni2+/Cd2+ complexes which were accommodated into three different kinds of coordination models in hexameric ring (H), dimeric ring (D), and 1D chain (C). The calculation indicates that both in the gas phase and water solvent, Zn–H and Ni–D have the lowest energies among the three different kinds of coordination models, respectively, which is in accordance with the experimental facts that Zn2+ cations adopt 5-coordinating geometry and form hexameric ring, while Ni2+ cations adopt 6-coordinating geometry and form dimeric ring. Although the Cd–C model in the gas phase does not have the lowest energy among the three different calculation models, its corresponding energy in the H2O solvent is indeed the lowest, which also supports the formation of 7-coordinating geometry and 1D chain in the crystal structure of Cd(II) complexes Cd-ClO 4 and Cd-BF 4 , and also manifests the significant influence of solvent molecules in the assembly process.
elements.clean_text: Table  lists the crystal data and structure refinement summary for complexes. Table  lists the energies of the Zn2+/Ni2+/Cd2+ complexes which were accommodated into three different kinds of coordination models in hexameric ring (H), dimeric ring (D), and 1D chain (C). The calculation indicates that both in the gas phase and water solvent, Zn-H and Ni-D have the lowest energies among the three different kinds of coordination models, respectively, which is in accordance with the experimental facts that Zn2+ cations adopt 5-coordinating geometry and form hexameric ring, while Ni2+ cations adopt 6-coordinating geometry and form dimeric ring. Although the Cd-C model in the gas phase does not have the lowest energy among the three different calculation models, its corresponding energy in the H2O solvent is indeed the lowest, which also supports the formation of 7-coordinating geometry and 1D chain in the crystal structure of Cd(II) complexes Cd-ClO  4  and Cd-BF  4 , and also manifests the significant influence of solvent molecules in the assembly process.

In summary, ten new Co/Zn/Ni/Mn/Cd complexes which display three types of isomorphous coordination frameworks, hexameric metallamacrocycles, dinuclear metallacycles, and 1D chiral chains, have been obtained in similar synthetic condition with two similar counteranions (ClO4 – and BF4 –). The X-ray single-crystal analyses and DFT calculations reveal that the coordination assembly process of the resulting complexes are directed by the metal ions, attributing to the size effect and restriction of the coordination geometry of the central metals and spacial conformation of the ligand. These results demonstrate how subtle changes in the metal–ligand synergistic cooperations can affect the outcome of a supramolecular self-assembly reaction.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, ten new Co/Zn/Ni/Mn/Cd complexes which display three types of isomorphous coordination frameworks, hexameric metallamacrocycles, dinuclear metallacycles, and 1D chiral chains, have been obtained in similar synthetic condition with two similar counteranions (ClO4 - and BF4 -). The X-ray single-crystal analyses and DFT calculations reveal that the coordination assembly process of the resulting complexes are directed by the metal ions, attributing to the size effect and restriction of the coordination geometry of the central metals and spacial conformation of the ligand. These results demonstrate how subtle changes in the metal-ligand synergistic cooperations can affect the outcome of a supramolecular self-assembly reaction.

elements.content: All chemicals were of reagent grade obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification.1H NMR spectra were measured on a Varian/Mercury-Plus 300 instrument. IR spectra were measured on a Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu–Kα, 1.5418 Å). The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Method

All chemicals were of reagent grade obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification.1H NMR spectra were measured on a Varian/Mercury-Plus 300 instrument. IR spectra were measured on a Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu-Kα, 1.5418 Å). The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer.

[Co<sub>6</sub>(AcNTB)<sub>6</sub>]·6ClO<sub>4</sub>·<italic toggle="yes">n</italic>H<sub>2</sub>O (Co-ClO<sub>4</sub>)

A solution of HAcNTB (0.025 mmol, 12 mg) in ethanol (EtOH, 5 mL) was carefully layered onto a solution of EtOH/CHCl3 (v/v = 1:2, 9 mL) of Co(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.025 mmol, 10 mg) in a glass tube. The resulting solution was left at room temperature for two weeks and block red crystals were obtained. Yield: about 60%. Calcd. for C156H224N42Cl6Cu6O82 ([Cu 6 (AcNTB) 6 ]·6ClO 4 ·46H 2 O):N 12.88; C 41.04; H 4.94. Found: N 12.78; C 40.95; H 4.77%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3409(s), 1623(s), 1543(w), 1494(m), 1478(m), 1455(s), 1384(m), 1314(m), 1090(s), 748(m), 627(m).

elements.content:
Caution! Perchlorate salts and complexes in the presence of organic ligands are potentially explosive. Only a small amount of material should be used and handled with care.

X-ray Crystallography

Suitable single crystals of complexes Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , Zn-BF 4 , Ni-ClO 4 , Ni-BF 4 , Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 were selected and mounted onto thin glass fibers. X-ray intensity data were measured at 150 K on an Oxford Gemini S Ultra diffractometer with the Enhance X-ray Source of Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) or Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) using the ω–φ scan technique. Empirical absorption correction was applied using spherical harmonics implemented in SCALE3 ABSPACK scaling algorithm. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares against F 2 of all data using the SHELXTL program package.Anisotropical thermal factors were assigned to most of the non-hydrogen atoms except those showing severe disorder. The positions of the hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically, assigned isotropic thermal parameters, and allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms before the final cycle of least-squares refinement. In Co-ClO 4 , there are large amounts of free water molecules which are distributed over partial sites and refined with displacement parameters approximately isotropically. H atoms are not added. In 1-BF 4 , the BF4 – anion is modeled by making all B–F bonds similar, and the CHCl3 and water molecules are refined with partial occupancy. No H atoms are added for water molecules. In Zn-ClO 4 , the ClO4 – anion is disordered with O atoms occupying two sets of positions. The Cl–O bonds are fixed the same. The CHCl3 and water molecules are disordered and refined with displacement parameters approximately isotropically. Due to poor crystallinity, a low observed/unique reflection ratio is obtained. No H atoms are added for water molecules. In Zn-BF 4 , the large amount of free water molecules are distributed over disordered positions and refined with displacement parameters approximately isotropically. In Ni-ClO 4 , the free water molecules are disordered and refined without H atoms, while the coordinating water molecules are refined with H atoms fixed in a reasonable distance. In Ni-BF 4 , the BF4 – anion is disordered over two fractional positions and refined freely without restraints. In Mn-ClO 4 , the ClO4 – anion is disordered over two sets of positions and refined resembling isotropically. In Mn-BF 4 , the free water molecules are refined without H atoms. In Cd-ClO 4 , the ClO4 – anion is disordered over two sets of positions. All anions and solvent molecules are modeled and refined with displacement parameters approximately isotropically. In Cd-BF 4 , the BF4 – anion is disordered over two sets of positions with all F atoms refined resembling isotropically. No H atoms are added for water molecules. CCDC reference numbers 822696–822705. For crystallographic data in CIF or other electronic format see DOI: xxxxxxxxxx.

elements.content: All calculations were performed with the Gaussian 03 software package using the default convergence criteria. Models created from fragments of the crystal structures were used as starting points. Geometry optimizations were conducted in both gas phase and water solvent using self-consistent B3LYP density functional methods. In terms of disk space, computer time and the size of the molecules studied here, the standard 6-31G* basis set was used for the light atoms C, H, N, O, and LANL2DZ for metal ions.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

All calculations were performed with the Gaussian 03 software package using the default convergence criteria. Models created from fragments of the crystal structures were used as starting points. Geometry optimizations were conducted in both gas phase and water solvent using self-consistent B3LYP density functional methods. In terms of disk space, computer time and the size of the molecules studied here, the standard 6-31G* basis set was used for the light atoms C, H, N, O, and LANL2DZ for metal ions.

A solution of HAcNTB (0.025 mmol, 12 mg) in ethanol (EtOH, 5 mL) was carefully layered onto a solution of EtOH/CHCl3 (v/v = 1:2, 9 mL) of Co(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.025 mmol, 10 mg) in a glass tube. cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Representation of Three Series of Isomorphous Structures Induced by Different Metal Cations: Hexameric Ring in Co-ClO  4 , Co-BF  4 , Zn-ClO  4  and Zn-BF  4 ; Dimeric Ring in Ni-ClO  4  and Ni-BF  4 ; and 1D Chain in Mn-ClO  4 , Mn-BF  4 , Cd-ClO  4 , and Cd-BF  4

cln_elements.content: Representative crystal structures of Co-ClO 4 , Co-BF 4 , Zn-ClO 4 , and Zn-BF 4 : (a) coordination geometry of M2+ cation (M2+ = Co2+/Zn2+, teal; N, blue; C, gray; O, red (in one ligand) and purple (from another ligand) showing fan-like conformation of the AcNTB– ligand; (b) space-filling diagram of the 3D framework viewed along [100] showing huge hydrophilic voids; (c) hexameric ring [M6AcNTB6]6+ showing twelve N–H···O hydrogen bonds in red dash lines, intramolecular π–π interactions in blue dash lines, and central metal ions in polyhedra (three benzimidazole groups in each ligand shown in different color for clarity); (d) hexameric ring [M6AcNTB6]6+ showing the hydrophobic cavity inside the ring highlighted by yellow ball. All guest molecules are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Representative crystal structures of Co-ClO  4 , Co-BF  4 , Zn-ClO  4 , and Zn-BF  4 : (a) coordination geometry of M2+ cation (M2+ = Co2+/Zn2+, teal; N, blue; C, gray; O, red (in one ligand) and purple (from another ligand) showing fan-like conformation of the AcNTB- ligand; (b) space-filling diagram of the 3D framework viewed along [100] showing huge hydrophilic voids; (c) hexameric ring [M6AcNTB6]6+ showing twelve N-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds in red dash lines, intramolecular π-π interactions in blue dash lines, and central metal ions in polyhedra (three benzimidazole groups in each ligand shown in different color for clarity); (d) hexameric ring [M6AcNTB6]6+ showing the hydrophobic cavity inside the ring highlighted by yellow ball. All guest molecules are omitted for clarity.

cln_elements.content: Representative crystal structures of Ni-ClO 4 and Ni-BF 4 , (a) coordination geometry of Ni2+ cation (Ni2+, teal; N, blue; C, gray; O, red (from another ligand) and purple (from water molecule) showing pincer-like conformation of AcNTB– ligand; and (b) dinuclear [Ni2AcNTB2(H2O)2]2+ ring showing intramolecular hydrogen bonds (green dash lines).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Representative crystal structures of Ni-ClO  4  and Ni-BF  4 , (a) coordination geometry of Ni2+ cation (Ni2+, teal; N, blue; C, gray; O, red (from another ligand) and purple (from water molecule) showing pincer-like conformation of AcNTB- ligand; and (b) dinuclear [Ni2AcNTB2(H2O)2]2+ ring showing intramolecular hydrogen bonds (green dash lines).

cln_elements.content: Representative crystal structures of Mn-ClO 4 , Mn-BF 4 , Cd-ClO 4 , and Cd-BF 4 : (a) coordination geometry of M2+ cation (M2+ = Mn2+/Cd2+, teal; N, blue; C, gray; O, red (in one ligand) and purple (from another ligand) showing fan-like conformation of the AcNTB– ligand; (b) 1D chiral chain bridged through bidentate acetate groups; (c) intermolecular π–π interactions between 1D chains showing in purple dash lines for face-to-face π–π interactions and in green and teal dash lines for two kinds of face-to-edge π–π interactions; and (d) space-filling diagram showing anions (ClO4 – for Mn-ClO 4 and Cd-ClO 4 , BF4 – for Mn-BF 4 and Cd-BF 4 ) and guest water molecules in the channel viewed along [001].
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Representative crystal structures of Mn-ClO  4 , Mn-BF  4 , Cd-ClO  4 , and Cd-BF  4 : (a) coordination geometry of M2+ cation (M2+ = Mn2+/Cd2+, teal; N, blue; C, gray; O, red (in one ligand) and purple (from another ligand) showing fan-like conformation of the AcNTB- ligand; (b) 1D chiral chain bridged through bidentate acetate groups; (c) intermolecular π-π interactions between 1D chains showing in purple dash lines for face-to-face π-π interactions and in green and teal dash lines for two kinds of face-to-edge π-π interactions; and (d) space-filling diagram showing anions (ClO4 - for Mn-ClO  4  and Cd-ClO  4 , BF4 - for Mn-BF  4  and Cd-BF  4 ) and guest water molecules in the channel viewed along [001].

cln_elements.content: Representation of different coordination structures assembled from six different transition metal ions in the periodic table of elements. The numbers below the cation symbols represent the cations’ radii (Å).

cln_elements.content: Theoretical view of the three different coordination models, (a) fragment in hexameric metallacycle (abbreviated as M-H); (b) fragment in dinuclear metallacycle (abbreviated as M-D); and (c) fragment in 1D chain (abbreviated as M–C). M = Zn, Ni, Cd.
